For what purposes is each computer used.
What is the nature of the data stored by each computer.
What interconnections exist or will exist between any of these computers.
Who has access to each computer.
What savings in staff numbers have been achieved or are anticipated as a result of the installation or operation of each computer.

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honourable member's question is as follows:

item.para: The Department of Primary Industry owns four and rents one mim computer. The Statutory Authorities under the Minister's control own a total of twenty-one computers with one on order and one being rented. The answers for questions 2-7 are set out below in respect of each computer within the Department of Primary Industry and in respect of all computers owned or rented by each Statutory Authority.

subdebate.1.para: Department of Primary Industry
Computer No. 1 and No. 2- Bureau of Animal Health

item.para: The cost of these computers was $29,000 each.
Both computers are used in the development, implementation and running of the Australian National Animal Disease Information System.
Information stored consists of detailed records of activitites associated with eradication of bovine brucellosis in Australia.
Information is able to be transferred at present by computer medium (disk or diskette).
Only scientific officers employed full time by the Australian Bureau of Animal Health have access to each computer.
The computers have been an integral feature of the program from the outset and no staff savings have therefore resulted from their use.

subdebate.1.para: Computer No. 3- Bureau of Agricultural Economics

item.para: The purchase cost was $ 109,000.
3 ) This computer is used to provide a data entry service.

Bureau of Agricultural Economics (BAE) rural industry survey and other data are captured on this data entry system and then transferred onto magnetic tape to the CSIRO computing network (CSIRONET) for further processing. Information is not permanently stored on this computer.
Other than this transfer to CSIRONET, there are no connections to other computers.
Only authorized departmental staff have access to this computer.

No staff savings have resulted from the implementation of this data entry system. However, its greater throughput capacity on data in more complex forms has enabled a greater workload to be dealt with by existing staff

subdebate.1.para: Computer No. 4- Bureau of Agricultural Economics

item.para: This computer was purchased at a cost of $28,400.
It performs as a communications controller giving remote job entry and inter-active access to the CSIRONET computer service bureau.

This computer's linkage to CSIRONET is used to process and store a wide range of data both for the BAE and some other Divisions of the Department. The data stored includes extensive holdings of raw and processed data from BAE rural industry surveys, raw and processed data from surveys of Australian fishing industries, files of data which are extracted from the publications of other organisations both in Australia and overseas which form important input into BAE analyses and files of data to facilitate departmental management, for example, mailing list and file registry information.
Apart from the connection to CSIRONET, this computer is not connected to any other computers.
Only authorized departmental officers have access to this computer.

This computer replaced earlier forms of access to CSIRONET and has not resulted in any staff savings. However, since the Department and the BAE in particular, commenced using CSIRONET computer facilities in the early 1960s substantially increased workloads associated with the processing of survey data, the computations associated with economic analyses and the management of departmental information have been absorbed without a commensurate increase in staff.

subdebate.1.para: Computer No. 5- Management Services Branch

item.para: ) This computer was rented from CSIRONET at the beginning of 1978 at a cost of $95 1 per month.

It performs as a communications controller giving remote job entry and inter-active access to the CSIRONET computer service bureau. It was leased specifically for the purpose of processing claims made on the Beef Industry Incentive Payments Scheme (BHPS).
Information on BHPS claims and payments is maintained by CSIRONET.
Apart from the telecommunication link to CSIRONET this computer is not connected to any other.
Only authorised departmental officers have access to this computer.
This computer has been an integral feature of the program from the outset and no staff savings have therefore resulted from its use.

subdebate.1.para: Statutory Authorities Australian Dairy Corporation

item.para: The Australian Dairy Corporation owns two computers, the purchase cost of each being $29,142 and $187,438.
3 ) Both computers are used for processing of information and statistics required by the Corporation to perform its functions as specified in the Dairy Product Act.

The data stored in the computer is of the nature required to enable the Corporation to distribute certain revenue to the industry, to enable maintenance of production statistics, and to enable proper exercising of the export permit controls.
There are and will be no inter-connection between these computers or with computers outside the Corporation.
Only authorised Corporation personnel have access to each computer.

It is not possible to quantify precisely any savings in staff numbers that have been achieved. It would, however, have been necessary to employ additional staff if the functions now being carried out by the computer had to be performed manually.

subdebate.1.para: Australian Wool Testing Authority

item.para: The Australian Wool Testing Authority owns and operates sixteen computers and has one on order. None are rented. The total cost of these computers is $554,233.

The purposes for which these computers are used are as follows: management and financial accounting; quality control monitoring and scientific computation of wool testing data plus production of final printed certificate; data entry, preparation and verification; data entry and calculations; data preparation and calculations.
Data stored are test measurements plus adequate sample identification to verify the validity of certificates issued, as required by international testing standards.
No interconnections exist with external computers or between AWTA laboratories. None are planned for the foreseeable future.
Only authorised AWTA operators and staff have access.

The AWTA installed these computers to enable an expansion of testing services. There have been no direct staff savings but additional staff would otherwise have been required to handle the large growth of these services.

subdebate.1.para: Australian Wool Corporation

item.para: The Corporation rents one computer on a five year lease at a cost of $ 1 80,000 per annum.
Administrative support for all AWC functions, including the Reserve Price Scheme and government and industry statistics.

Data stored on the computer is directly related to functions carried out by the AWC, such as wool statistics, inventory details, raw wool sales, economic models of wool forecasting plus general administrative data.
No interconnection exists.
Permanent staff of the AWC employed in the ADP Department and maintenance staff for the computer supplier.

No direct savings are evident, since the computer was installed at the same time as the then Commission commenced its responsibilities. The responsibilities since that time have grown considerably; however, staff numbers and ADP equipment levels have remained below this rate of increase.

subdebate.1.para: Australian Wheat Board

item.para: The Australian Wheat Board owns one computer costing $305,000.
The primary objective of the computer is to facilitate payments to growers. The other purposes to which the computer is put to use are:

subdebate.1.para: Stock, shipping and marketing statistics.
Recording term payments due on credit sales.
Processing daily selling price data.
Cheque reconciliations.
Sundry reports for Australian Barley Board, Victorian Grain Elevators Board and Vicrail.

item.para: The nature of data stored in the computer is detailed below according to each of the computer functions:

subdebate.1.para: Payments to growers.
Stock/shipping/marketing statistics. credit sales/shipments.
Daily price lists/sundry reports. cheque reconciliations.

item.para: The only interconnection or interaction between the Board's computer and any other computer is in respect of magnetic tape supplied by the Reserve Bank of Australia detailing paid cheques during a specified period.
Other than very occasional use of the computer by Honeywell during non-working hours, the only access to the computer is by the A. W.B. computer staff.

There have been no savings in staff numbers, although the advent of the computer has reduced the need for the employment of casual staff during the payment period. The major saving to the Board has been in the area of avoiding the costs which would otherwise have been payable to the Computer Service Bureau.

subdebate.1.para: Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation

item.para: The AMLC owns 2 computers costing $39,800 and $60,000.
Both machines are used for processing the Corporation's internal data management requirements.
Data stored consists of payroll, superannuation, meat export statistics and internal financial information.
Both machines share an interchangeable central processing unit.
Access is restricted to authorised personnel.
No staff savings have been made to date but it is expected that some will occur in the future through natural attrition as the range of applications being computerised expands.

DEPARTMENT OF PRIMARY INDUSTRY
Computer No. 1 and No. 2- Bureau of Animal Health

item.para: Data stored relates to the National Brucellosis Eradication Campaign. and (3) The BAE and Fisheries Division published reports of their research and analyses many of which involve information stored on CSIRONET.
